title: Wessex Ridgeway Walking Route

images.title: michael ely / Shillingstone Hill, Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: Shillingstone Hill, Wessex Ridgeway. The trig pillar (known as Shilling Stone Hill to the OS) is 223 metres above sea level. This area is part of Blandford Forest. Looking south from the Wessex Ridgeway footpath/bridleway.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Gallops by the Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: Gallops by the Wessex Ridgeway. The gallops are in the foreground. The clump of trees in the valley beyond the gate marks the position of Manton House Farm.

images.title: Phil Williams / Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: A view looking to the southeast towards a junction of a public footpath (right)and a bridleway forming part of the Wessex Ridgeway (Left) on the lane between Chicklade and Hindon.

images.title: Rupert Fleetingly / Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: A dog surveys the countryside from the trail. Looking north along the bridleway on Buckland Down.

images.title: Mike Searle / Crockers Farmhouse from the Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: Crockers Farmhouse from the Wessex Ridgeway. This farm is located on the minor road between Mappowder and Higher Ansty. The long distance footpath passes through the farm.

images.title: Doug Lee / Morgan's Hill from Wessex Ridgeway
images.caption: Morgan's Hill from the Ridgeway. The ridgeway is also visible climbing the hill towards the antennae (located in SU0367) to the left of which is the golf course. Furze Knoll in SU0366 can also be seen on the skyline.

images.title: Andrew Smith / The Wessex Ridgeway, Maiden Newton
images.caption: At Maiden Newton. Descending into the Frome valley between a fields of wheat and mown hay. Combe Bottom falls steeply away to the right of the track which is only a public footpath at this point. The Hog Cliff Bottom National Nature Reserve is also located in this area.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Wessex Ridgeway on Roundway Down
images.caption: On Roundway Down. Long dusty lane heading east over this chalky down, not far from the battlefield site.

description: This wonderful trail runs from Marlborough in Wiltshire to Lyme Regis on the Jurassic Coast in Dorset. You will pass: - Overton Down - The mystical Avebury Stones - The White Horse at Bratton -  Wardour Castle ruins - Ibberton Hill with splendid views -The Vale of Pewsey - Salisbury Plain - Pilsdon Pen - with panoramic views of Marshwood Vale - Lewesdon Hill the highest point in the county of Dorset. - Cerne Abbas Giant - the mysterious figure on Giant Hill in Dorset thought to have been created in the 17th century - Win Green Hill , the highest point in the Cranborne Chase AONB - Bulbarrow Hill - this Iron Age Hill fort near Blandform Forum command wonderful views over Blackmore Vale. Roundway Hill - the site of a 1643 Civil War battle, also includes the Oliver's Castle Iron Age Hillfort.
